(magazine)|Spin]]'' |rev7score = (7/10){{cite book |url=http://www.acclaimedmusic.net/Current/A1711.htm |title=Spin Alternative Record Guide |first=Eric |last=Weisbard |date={{date|October 10, 1995}} |publisher=Vintage |edition=1st |isbn=978-0679755746}} |rev8 = [[Yahoo! Music]] |rev8score = (mixed){{cite web |url=http://ca.music.yahoo.com/read/review/12041749 |title=(Symbol) |first=Jennifer |last=Clay |date={{date|10/13/1992}} |publisher=[[Yahoo! Music]] |accessdate={{date|2011-09-16}} |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5rQCZ8p7z |archivedate={{date|2010-07-22}} |deadurl=no}} }} [[File:Prince logo.svg|15px]] is the fourteenth [[studio album]] by American recording artist [[Prince (musician)|Prince]], released October 13, 1992 on [[Paisley Park Records|Paisley Park]] and [[Warner Bros. Records]].{{cite web |url=http://www.discogs.com/artist/Prince+%26+The+New+Power+Generation |title=Prince & The New Power Generation Discography |publisher=[[Discogs]] |accessdate={{date|2009-04-15}}}} Due to its official title being an unpronounceable symbol, which Prince later adopted as his name, the album has been referred to as the '''''Love Symbol Album''''', or simply '''''Symbol'''''. It is Prince's second album to feature his backing group, [[The New Power Generation]], which received co-billing for the release. The album contains elements of musical styles including [[funk]], [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]], [[Hip hop music|hip hop]], [[jazz]], [[reggae]], and [[synthpop]].{{cite web |url=http://www.discogs.com/Prince-The-New-Power-Generation-Untitled-Symbol/release/1662802 |title=Prince And The New Power Generation* â Untitled (Symbol) |publisher=[[Discogs]] |accessdate={{date|2009-04-16}}}} The album's first two singles, "[[My Name Is Prince]]" and "[[Sexy MF]]", achieved modest success on the US pop charts, though both made the top ten in the UK. Conversely, the third single, "[[7 (song)|7]]", was not as successful as the first two singles in the UK, but was a top ten hit in the US. The album was originally conceived as a "fantasy rock soap opera" with various spoken [[segue]]s throughout.{{Cite news | last =Willman| first = Chris| title = Prince's Latest Fleshed-Out Fantasy| newspaper = [[Los Angeles Times]] | date = {{date|October 11, 1992}} |publisher=Tribune Company |issn=0458-3035 |oclc=3638237 |url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/61717569.html?dids=61717569:61717569&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Oct+11%2C+1992&author=CHRIS+WILLMAN&pub=Los+Angeles+Times+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&desc=Prince's+Latest+Fleshed-Out+Fantasy+**+PRINCE+%26+THE+N.P.G.+%22(genders+merging+symbol)+%22+Paisley+Park%2FWarner+Bros.&pqatl=google}} However, in a last-minute attempt to add an additional song (Wanna Melt With U which was originally considered to be a b-side), most of the segues had to be cut for album length. The few that remained were somewhat confusing in context. The album debuts [[Mayte Garcia]], who plays a part in the album's storyline and would become Prince's wife in 1996. ''[[3 Chains o' Gold]]'', a direct-to-video film produced and directed by Prince, was released in 1994. The film is based on the plotline and songs of the ''Love Symbol Album'' and contained some of the original segues which were planned to be on the album.. ==Track listing== Produced, Arranged, and Performed by [[Prince (musician)|Prince]] and [[The New Power Generation]]. All songs composed by Prince except where noted. # "[[My Name Is Prince]]" (Prince, [[Tony M.|Tony Mosley]]) â 6:39 # "[[Sexy MF]]" (Prince, [[Levi Seacer, Jr.]], Tony Mosley) â 5:25 # "Love 2 the 9s" â 5:45 # "[[The Morning Papers]]" â 3:57 # "The Max" â 4:30 # "Segue" (spoken word with Prince and [[Kirstie Alley]]) â 0:21 # "Blue Light" â 4:38 # "I Wanna Melt with U" â 3:50 # "Sweet Baby" â 4:01 # "The Continental" â 5:31 # "[[Damn U]]" â 4:25 # "Arrogance" â 1:35 # "The Flow" (Prince, Tony Mosley) â 2:26 # "[[7 (song)|7]]" (Prince, [[Lowell Fulsom]], [[Jimmy McCracklin]]) â 5:13 # "And God Created Woman" â 3:18 # "3 Chains o' Gold" â 6:03 # "Segue" (spoken word with Prince and Kirstie Alley) â 1:30 # "The Sacrifice of Victor" â 5:41 ===Alternates=== "Segue" tracks do not appear on LP releases of the album. Several special editions of this album were released; one boxed set came with a bonus "Sexy MF" CD single, another with a special created CD single of "My Name Is Prince" mixes. ==Charts== {| class="wikitable" !align="left"|Chart (1992) !align="left"|Peak
position |- |align="left"|US [[Billboard 200]]{{Allmusic |class=album |id=r58223 |tab=charts-awards |label="''The Love Symbol Album'' > Charts & Awards > Billboard Albums" |accessdate={{date|2011-09-16}}}} |align="center"|5 |- |align="left"|US Billboard R&B Albums |align="center"|8 |- |align="left"|[[UK Albums Chart]]{{cite web |url=http://www.chartstats.com/release.php?release=46743 |title=Symbol |publisher=chartstats.com |accessdate={{date|2011-09-16}}}} |align="center"|1 |- |align="left"|Australian [[ARIA Charts|ARIA]] Albums Chart |align="center"|1 |- |} ==Singles and Hot 100 chart placings== * "[[Sexy MF]]" maxi-single (#66 US, #76 R&B, #4 UK) * "[[My Name Is Prince]]" maxi-single (#36 US, #25 R&B, #7 UK) * "[[7 (song)|7]]" maxi-single (#7 US, #3 R&B charts, #27 UK) * "[[Damn U]]" (#105 US, #32 R&B) * "[[The Morning Papers]]" maxi-single (#44 US, #8 R&B, #52 UK) {{s-start}} {{succession box | before = ''[[Automatic for the People]]'' by [[R.E.M.]] | title = [[List of number-one albums (UK)|UK number one album]] | years = October 17, 1992 â October 23, 1992 | after = ''[[Glittering Prize 81/92]]'' by [[Simple Minds]] }} {{succession box | before = ''[[Some Gave All]]'' by [[Billy Ray Cyrus]] | title = Australian [[ARIA Charts|ARIA Albums Chart]] [[Number-one albums of 1992 (Australia)|number-one album]] | years = October 25, 1992 â October 31, 1992 | after = ''[[Erotica (Madonna album)|Erotica]]'' by [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] }} {{end}} ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== *{{cite book| author = Nathan Brackett, Christian Hoard | title = The New Rolling Stone Album Guide: Completely Revised and Updated 4th Edition | publisher = Simon and Schuster | date = 2004 | location = | isbn = 0-7432-0169-8}} {{Prince}} [[Category:1992 albums]] [[Category:Prince (musician) albums]] [[Category:Albums produced by Prince (musician)]] [[Category:Paisley Park Records albums]] [[Category:Warner Bros.
